items.title: de'orbited satellite has elevation when calculated from tle
items.body:
Looking at **STARLINK-1220**, I see the following TLE:
```
STARLINK-1220
1 45211U 20012AK  20069.91667824  .00723224  00000-0  41594-2 0  9993
2 45211  53.0024 162.4808 0027451 118.7601 331.9927 15.75746283  3703
```
However ...
```
    tle_rec = ephem.readtle(name, line1, line2)
    tle_rec.compute()
    print(tle_rec.elevation)
```
... produces `364145470` (which of course, isn't right). For other deorbit'ed satellites I get `RuntimeError` and hence no Long/Lat or Elevation pair; but not for this one.

Any thoughts? Am I doing something wrong when trying to detect a deorbit'ed satellite?

items.title: Unexpected results between Python 2 and Python 3
items.body:
Hi

While creating a script for getting moon phase information I stumbled upon this weird problem.
In Python 2.7 I've got a time and date returned for the next full moon:

```
Python 2.7.18rc1 (default, Apr  7 2020, 12:05:55) 
[GCC 9.3.0] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import ephem
>>> ephem.next_full_moon('2020/06')
2020/6/5 19:12:21
```

But in Python 3 I get this:

```
Python 3.8.2 (default, Apr 27 2020, 15:53:34) 
[GCC 9.3.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import ephem
>>> ephem.next_full_moon('2020/06')
43986.300242368874
```

I get a floating point number returned instead of a date and time.
This also happens when I call every other emphem.next_... function.
ephem.now() gives also a floating point number.

Easiest way is to stick with Python 2 but that is EOL.

items.title: Sunrise and sunset are one hour off
items.body:
Ephem is around one hour to early for the sunrise and sunset. Here is my code, the google prediction (which is verified myself) and the ephem prediction. It is almost around one hour different. The datetime function is working correctly, so I do not think it has something todo with my setup:

```
print(datetime.datetime.now())
2020-03-12 11:51
```
Ephem: Float - Sunrise: 2020/3/13 **05:24:15** Sunset: 2020/3/12 **17:06:23**

Google result for the same date: Sunrise / Sunset : **06:27 / 18:06**

Can someone spot a mistake I made? I am using spyder3 with anaconda on debian with Python 3.7 and ephem-3.7.7.0.

```
def isTheSunShining(mydate, mytime):
 
     mycity = ephem.cities.city("Berlin")

     floatime_rise = mycity.next_rising(ephem.Sun())
     floatime_set = mycity.next_setting(ephem.Sun())
 
     print("Float - Sunrise: " + str(floatime_rise) + " Sunset: " + str(floatime_set))
```

items.title: Reproducing data from American Ephemeris
items.body:
### [edit] sorry, I'll check skyfield instead, and ask another question there, if I need to.


Hello @brandon-rhodes ,

This is a novice question.
  
I would like to use `pyephem` to reproduce the data found in the tables in "The American Ephemeris 1950-2050" by Neil F. Michelsen & Rique Pottenger, and use it for astrological calculations.

What would be the correct approach?

Thank you


![201907 - ephemerides](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6275531/61990618-942b3580-b076-11e9-8986-f4f33aac107a.png)

items.title: Wheels for newer Pythons on Windows
items.body: Currently Appveyor only builds wheels for Python 2.7, 3.3 and 3.4. It would be nice to also get wheels for 3.5+.

items.title: Help needed with moon tracking (Wrong position)
items.body:
So I'm trying to setup a satellite tracking system I firstly started to track the iss which prove to be unsuccesful. To verify that my tracking was correct I started tracking the moon  with this code

```
from datetime import datetime
import ephem
import  math
import time

iss = ephem.readtle('ISS',
    '1 25544U 98067A   19039.55403633  .00016717  00000-0  10270-3 0  9008',
    '2 25544  51.6404 280.9282 0005479   3.8234 356.2959 15.53222475 35269'
)

dpr = 180.0 / math.pi

place = ephem.Observer()
place.lon = 47.9667
place.lat = 7.4
place.elevation = 300
place.date = datetime.utcnow()

moon = ephem.Moon(place)

while True:
	place.date =  ephem.Date(ephem.localtime(ephem.now()))
	iss.compute(place)
	moon.compute(place)
	# print (iss.az * dpr , iss.alt * dpr)
	print (moon.az * dpr, moon.alt  * dpr)
	time.sleep(.1)
```

how ever the code give me results like this: `(127.19111336543878, 31.105173253858307)`  but the problem is that the moon is in plain west (The elevation is approximatively correct) at the time of writing that helps me think that there is an error in my code I just don't know where.

(Utc at the time of writing: `datetime.datetime(2019, 2, 12, 22, 57, 40, 353000)`)

items.title: Inconsistent interpretation of degrees vs radians based on the type used
items.body:
When specifying angle values like latitudes and longitudes, Ephem will interpret them as radians if specified as a float, and as degrees if specified as a string.

So:

```python
obs = ephem.Observer()
obs.lon = -118.0
# not the same as
obs.lon = "-118.0"
```

which seems easy to mix up

items.title: Refraction calculation excessive at negative horizons ?
items.body:
I found predicted moonrise times to be very early  (2-3 minutes) compared to observations for negative horizons. In this case, altitude was 1270 m which has an ocean horizon ~ -1.14 deg. This was for 1013 Pa and 14 deg C.

I picked out the refract.c  and ran refract.c alone and found that at -1.14deg Ta, refraction of  0.9 deg was being applied, resulting in *aa being set to ~ -2.04 deg !  Is this refraction calc invalid  for negative horizons ? I see there are a few methods around.

 I modified refract.c  so that the refraction correction would never exceed 34/60 and now  the moonrise times are very close  (seconds!) with exception of a moon elevation question I posted on stackoverflow.

Great software Brandon, nice work. I am using it for very low angle ham radio moonbounce  calculations for world records where the elevation of the moon is about 0.5 deg at each end , IE working at the antipodes, there is only a few minutes to make the communication.

regards
glen english
Canberra, Australia.

items.title: Pyephem appears to ignore the TLE second derivative of the mean motion
items.body:
The properties of an object read by readtle are `_M`, `_ap`, `_decay`, `_drag`, `_e`, `_epoch`, `_inc` , `_n`, `_orbit`, and `_raan`. These correspond to almost all the interesting elements in the TLE data. But it looks like the second derivative of the mean motion, from column 45–52 in line 1 of the TLE, is neither read nor stored.

Perhaps that element just isn't necessary, but I did a test where I took two adjacent TLE elements and computed their difference as a function of time, and their difference looks like a parabola, like one would expect if a second order term is missing. However, since I haven't compared the pyephem behavior to other implementations, this might be due to inherent inaccuracy in the TLE description rather than that term in particular.

items.title: 'Sun' transits below the horizon calculated for wrong day?
items.body:
Hi!
I'm using pyephem in conjunction with a smarthome tool. I want to get the altitude of the sun for a given location based on sunrise/sunset + an offset in degrees
Therefore I use the:
```
_obs.date = datetime.datetime.utcnow() # actually was 2018-09-08
_obs.horizon = str(doff) # set to a value too high
_obs.next_setting(self._orb, use_center=center).datetime() # get the sunrise with degree offset
```

The horizon defines the offset in degrees. Don't know if that gives a totally accurate result but it's good enough. Problem coming up, if doff is set higher than the sun will ever get on the requested day:
'Sun' transits below the horizon

That's pretty fine so far. So to avoid that problem I figure out noon and the position of the sun for noon to get the maximum altitude for that day. I then use that value -0.1 as the horizon doff above. I still get an error. It got obvious that the DATE is wrong. Not today but tomorrow.

`Error '06:00<sunrise+99<15:10' parsing time: 'Sun' transits below the horizon at 2018/9/9 11:18:59
`

Here are the calculations I used for my setup. I then queried the altitude for the sun at noon tomorrow, subtracted 0.01 to be sure and voila - everything works. Main problem still, that the difference even between the two days are about 5 minutes what is quite much. Is this behaviour on purpose?

midnight: 2018-09-07 23:19:29.907537+00:00, noon: 2018-09-08 11:19:19.628992+00:00, next noon: 2018-09-09 11:19:19.628992+00:00, max: 48.37995109887116, doff: 48.27995109887116, observer date 2018/9/8 11:19:20

items.title: Documentation is unclear about how to create angles, what values to pass to degrees() or hours()
items.body:
First, a question: is PyEphem still maintained or should I be switching to astropy?

The PyEphem documentation is very unclear about angles and how to create them or do math on them.

It says the only way to create an Angle is with degrees() or hours(), but it doesn't say what the argument should be. It says this:

> You can also create angles yourself through two ephem functions:
> degrees() — return an Angle in degrees
> hours() — return an Angle in hours

Through experimentation, I've found that calling degrees on a string representing works, but if I call degrees on a float, the argument needs to be in radians:

>>> seven_from_float = ephem.degrees(7.)
>>> seven_from_str = ephem.degrees('7')
>>> print(seven_from_float, seven_from_str)
401:04:13.6 7:00:00.0
>>> print(seven_from_float.norm, seven_from_str)
41:04:13.6 7:00:00.0
>>> seven_from_radians = ephem.degrees(7 * math.pi / 180.)
>>> print(seven_from_radians)
7:00:00.0

Hours does pretty much the same thing: initialized from a string, it wants hours, but from a float, it wants radians.

It's easy enough to make those conversions, but it's not what I would have expected from the documentation and took a while to experiment and figure out what I needed.

items.title: Potential incorrect geodetic to geocentric latitude conversion
items.body:
Hi there, I was going through the `earthsat.c` file in `pyephem/libastro-3.7.7/earthsat.c` and in the method `GetSitPosition(...),` Line 637, I noticed you had:

`Lat = atan(1/(1-SQR(EarthFlat))*tan(SiteLat));`

I checked MATLAB (their function `geocentricLatitude `-- which takes the geodetic latitude and flattening factor as inputs) as well as David Vallado's book _Fundamentals of Astrodynamics and Applications_ and found those resources are consistent on how to calculate the geocentric latitude from the geodetic latitude when you are on the surface of the ellipsoid. Following their lead, I believe the correct expression is:

`Lat = atan(SQR(1-EarthFlat)*tan(SiteLat));`

In Vallado's book, the expression is on pg. 148 and provides it in terms of eccentricity, but it's a simple matter to convert that to be a function of the flattening factor.

items.title: Observer.radec_of() applies corrections inconsistently
items.body:
An observer object can translate local azimuth and altitude coordinates into astrometric RA/Dec by calling [`Observer.radec_of()`](https://github.com/brandon-rhodes/pyephem/blob/master/extensions/_libastro.c#L940-L972)

If the observer epoch is set to a special [`EOD`](https://github.com/brandon-rhodes/pyephem/blob/master/libastro-3.7.7/astro.h#L73) (= epoch of the date) value, then `radec_of()` will skip trying to precess the RA/Dec to a desired epoch:

`
     if (o->now.n_epoch != EOD)
	  ap_as(&o->now, o->now.n_epoch, &ra, &dec);
`

The trouble is that [`ap_as()`](https://github.com/brandon-rhodes/pyephem/blob/master/libastro-3.7.7/ap_as.c#L6-L44) also attempts to apply stellar aberration and solar deflection corrections. Applying these corrections **should not** depend on the epoch. Additionally, `ap_as()` corrects for the nutation between present and requested epochs. The corrections are combined in [`obj_fixed()`](https://github.com/brandon-rhodes/pyephem/blob/master/libastro-3.7.7/circum.c#L207-L299). This issue is made less significant by the fact `pyephem` does not appear to make `EOD` available directly, although using the numeric value from `astro.h` still works.

Furthermore, in [this answer](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11970713/pyephem-conversion-of-alt-az-to-ra-dec-and-back-not-internally-consistent#12487265) it is suggested that `radec_of()` should **not** apply the aberration correction, seemingly contradicting the behavior now in place. Currently, aberration, deflection and nutation are applied whenever the observer epoch is not `EOD`. 

It was suggested in the above answer that `Observer` might support different flavors of `radec_of()`, some applying the aberration correction and some not. This way users would have control over which coordinate distortions are corrected for. An obvious specialization would be with and without the "fixed" source corrections (aberration and deflection). Both specializations should include nutation.

items.title: PyEphem compatibility with new versions of Python
items.body:
I am new to Python and PyEphem.  I have found an issue using pyephem 3.7.6.0 and python 3.6.3 on Windows 10.  While testing the Observer example in the Quick Reference, I found a problem creating an Observer.  Below is the example:

```
>>> lowell = ephem.Observer()
>>> lowell.lon = '-111:32.1'
>>> lowell.lat = '35:05.8'
>>> lowell.elevation = 2198
>>> lowell.date = '1986/3/13'
>>> j = ephem.Jupiter()
>>> j.compute(lowell)
>>> print(j.circumpolar)
False
>>> print(j.neverup)
False
>>> print('%s %s' % (j.alt, j.az))
0:57:44.7 256:41:01.3
```

When I type this line-by-line into the Python Shell, it works perfectly fine.  But if I put the exact same code into a .py program, it will throw the following error when executed:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:/Python/Programs/ephem observer.py", line 1, in <module>
    import ephem
  File "C:/Python/Programs\ephem.py", line 8, in <module>
    gatech = ephem.Observer()
AttributeError: module 'ephem' has no attribute 'Observer'
```

I installed Python 2.7.14 to test this issue on an older version, and the code runs without error.

1) For Python 3.6.4, I am curious why the code works when typed line-by-line into the shell, but does not work if you run it all as a program.
2) What is the latest version of Python that PyEphem is known to work with?

Jason

This was the code I used:

    import ephem

    obs.long = 19.0402
    iss = ephem.readtle('ISS', '1 25544U 98067A   17259.02218116  .00016717  00000-0  10270-3 0  9035', '2 25544  51.6420 305.5126 0004198 283.5006  76.5679 15.54215637 35870')

**System:** 
Ubuntu 16.04 Python 2.7

**Steps to reproduce:**

First python file, ephem: 
```
#!/usr/bin/python
# -*- coding:utf-8 -*-


import ephem
import datetime

obs = ephem.Observer()
obs.pressure = 0
obs.horizon = '-6'
obs.lat, obs.lon = 24.492, 54.439
obs.elevation = 0

obs.date = datetime.datetime.strptime("2017-05-20 00:00:00", "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S")

print obs.date
    
next_rising = obs.next_rising(ephem.Sun())
```

```
#!/usr/bin/python
```

items.title: Modifying satellite parameters
items.body:
I am working on fitting EarthSatellite orbits to observations.  This includes creating a satellite from a TLE, then `newsat = sat.copy()`, and changing attributes such as `newsat._n`, `newsat.catalog_number`.

I am getting wild-pointer type behavior, specifically after changing the catalog number (although this may just be the one that manifests in my test case).  This behavior includes `newsat.catalog_number = 12345` leading to the original `sat.catalog_number` changing type from `int` to `Angle`, a dictionary entry that contained `sat` changing its key (was the catalog_number, but gets changed to a different integer) and, shortly thereafter, a segmentation violation crash.

So questions:
1) Is it legitimate to modify the orbital parameters, catalog_number, name, etc. of an EarthSatellite object?
2) I notice in _libastro.c that some parameters are in `PyGetSetDef EarthSatellite_getset` and others are in `PyMemberDef EarthSatellite_members`.  Does that mean 'you can change these but not those'?
3) When you copy a `ephem.Body`, it calls `Body_copy()`, I believe.  `EarthSatellite` is a subclass of `Body`, but it also includes `PyObject` pointers for name and catalog_number.  Do those get properly initialized with pointers to `new`ed PyObjects containing copies?

Sorry I don't have a simple reliable test case.

I am trying to use PyEphem in order to carry out some preliminary mission analysis calculations. In this case, I need to define the spacecraft in terms of potential altitude, inclination, RAAN and such; instead of using any pre-defined spacecraft (either from a database or through a TLE).

In the documentation, I've seen that this option is supported by directly changing the parameter from the "EarthSatellite" body type. The following is the list of parameters to be changed:

- _n — Mean motion, in revolutions per day
- _inc — Inclination (°)
- _raan — Right Ascension of ascending node (°)
- _e — Eccentricity
- _ap — Argument of perigee at epoch (°)
- _M — Mean anomaly from perigee at epoch (°)
- _decay — Orbit decay rate in revolutions per day, per day
- _drag — Object drag coefficient in per earth radii
- _orbit — Integer orbit number of epoch

Any example with the amount of parameters that necessarily need to be changed?

items.title: next_pass returns mixed results when satellite overhead
items.body:
From the docs, we assume next_pass to return "when it will next cross above the horizon". However, if you call on an object when it is currently overhead the return will be a mix of fields that are calculated against the current pass and fields that are calculated for the next pass:
- Rise time shows next pass
- Rise azimuth shows next pass
- Maximum altitude time shows current pass
- Maximum altitude shows current pass
- Set time shows current pass
- Set azimuth shows current pass

In the following example the object was overhead for the first observer.date, with a rise time of 19:09:21 (per another app, which matched the set time closely). The expectation is that the overhead pass is ignored completely and the results from the second observer.date should all be the same.

This is with pyephem 3.7.6.0, linux. Underlying bug behind satnogs/satnogs-network#199

``` python
import ephem
import math


observer = ephem.Observer()
observer.lat = "39.236"
observer.lon = "-86.3053"
observer.elevation = 286

observer.date = "2016/3/19 19:17:19"

sat_ephem = ephem.readtle("ITAMSAT (IO-26)",
                          "1 22826U 93061D   16078.88578765  .00000055  00000-0  38689-4 0  9993",
                          "2 22826  98.7432  34.7612 0008331 207.2611 152.8135 14.30268351172493")

print "observer date: " + str(observer.date)
tr, azr, tt, altt, ts, azs = observer.next_pass(sat_ephem)
print "altitude: " + format(math.degrees(altt), '.0f') + " rising from: " + format(math.degrees(azr), '.0f')
print "rise time: " + str(tr)

observer.date = "2016/3/19 19:30:00"
print "\n\nobserver date: " + str(observer.date)
tr, azr, tt, altt, ts, azs = observer.next_pass(sat_ephem)
print "altitude: " + format(math.degrees(altt), '.0f') + " rising from: " + format(math.degrees(azr), '.0f')
print "rise time: " + str(tr)
```

Gives us:

```
observer date: 2016/3/19 19:17:19
altitude: 46 rising from: 202
rise time: 2016/3/19 20:49:28


observer date: 2016/3/19 19:30:00
altitude: 21 rising from: 202
rise time: 2016/3/19 20:49:28
```

cheers!

items.title: Rise/set times not taking account of observer elevation
items.body:
I'm experiencing with Python and PyEphem, while playing I wrote this simple script:

``` python
import ephem

citta = ephem.Observer()
sole = ephem.Sun()
citta.temp = 20
citta.pressure = 1013
citta.lat = "46:00.0"
citta.lon = "09:09.0"
citta.elevation = 0

citta.date = "2016/2/13"

print(citta)
for giorno in range(1,10):
    alba = citta.next_rising(sole)
    mezzogiorno = citta.next_transit(sole)
    tramonto = citta.next_setting(sole)
    print('%s %s %s' % (alba, mezzogiorno, tramonto))
    citta.date += 1
```

While comparing results with other softwares I realized that changing citta.elevation value doesn't change rise and set times.

items.title: TLEs fail to parse with pyephem but succeed with sgp4
items.body:
I have two TLEs that parse ok with sgp4 but fail with pyephem.  running pyephem v3.7.5.3

If it matters, I am running:
python 3.4.3
ubuntu 15.04

Here's a script to reproduce the issue:

```
import ephem
from sgp4.earth_gravity import wgs84
from sgp4.io import twoline2rv

tle1 = ("1 99998U          16033.50000000 -.00000082  00000-0 -21065-5 0 00007",
        "2 99998 055.0190 359.9965 0008971 268.7611 091.2409 15.38670435000017")

tle2 = ("1 99997U          16033.50000000 -.00000327  00000-0 -81943-5 0 00000",
        "2 99997 045.0203 000.0034 0007772 267.0094 092.9891 15.39231281000013")

print('ephem.version:', ephem.__version__)

# this works
sat1 = twoline2rv(tle1[0], tle1[1], wgs84)
sat2 = twoline2rv(tle2[0], tle2[1], wgs84)
print(sat1.error)  # 0 as expected.
print(sat2.error)  # 0 as expected.

# this throws ValueError: line does not conform to tle format
try:
    sat1 = ephem.readtle("TEST", tle1[0], tle1[1])
except ValueError as e:
    print(e)

try:
    sat2 = ephem.readtle("TEST", tle2[0], tle2[1])
except ValueError as e:
    print(e)
```

Output of the script:

```
ephem.version: 3.7.5.3
0
0
line does not conform to tle format
line does not conform to tle format
```

items.title: PyEphem excepts UTC datetime object while datetime is localtime by default
items.body:
Recently I was bitten by the following code:

```
from datetime import datetime
import ephem

# compute moon altitude from UNIX timestamp
timestamp = 1264368023

# location/time
SciencePark = ephem.Observer()
SciencePark.lat = '52.355918'
SciencePark.long = '4.9511453'
SciencePark.elevation = 0
SciencePark.date = datetime.fromtimestamp(timestamp)

print SciencePark

m = ephem.Moon(SciencePark)
print m.alt
```

Observer.date expects a UTC datetime object! 

The following does work:

```
SciencePark.date = datetime.utcfromtimestamp(timestamp)
```

IMHO, The documentation is not clear about this. Only localtime datetime objects are mentioned.

I will try to write some additional documentation and will send a pull request.

items.title: Wrong ephemeris for asteroids after MPCORB database change
items.body:
Recently, the MPCORB database changed its standard epoch. Then pyephem failed to calculate the position of asteroids.

Take Asteroid 2001 BP25 on 2015-11-23.55 UT as an example. With the old and new standard epochs, I calculated its position as follows:

```
import ephem
import datetime

tobs = ephem.Date( datetime.datetime(2015, 11, 23, 13, 12, 13) ) # observation time

obj = ephem.readdb( "2001 BP25 0,e,3.47304,134.76688,294.08950,2.4271529,0.26065039,0.2231376,330.92520,06/27.0/2015,2000,H 16.0,0.15" ) # old orbital elements
obj.compute( tobs )
print "With old orbital elements, ra = %.6f rad, dec = %.5f rad" % ( obj.a_ra, obj.a_dec )

obj = ephem.readdb( "2001 BP25 0,e,3.47303,134.76696,294.10956,2.4270882,0.26066081,0.2231111,23.04368,01/12.0/2016,2000,H 16.1,0.15" ) # new orbital elements
obj.compute( tobs )
print "With new orbital elements, ra = %.6f rad, dec = %.5f rad" % ( obj.a_ra, obj.a_dec )
```

Then I obtained the following output:

```
With old orbital elements, ra = 1.879871 rad, dec = 0.30927 rad
With new orbital elements, ra = 1.891992 rad, dec = 0.30874 rad
```

The online IAU MP checker confirmed the coordinates calculated with the old orbital elements.

Therefore, I am wondering: is there some constant in pyephem that should be changed for the new standard epoch?

items.title: Decayed satellite causing code to hang
items.body:
I have been trying to plot the position of a large number of satellites using pyephem from a database.  However, when I try and plot the following, it gets stuck in an infinite loop (making it difficult to detect and avoid)

```
import ephem
tle = ("0 MOLNIYA 1-42",                                                                                                                       
       "1 11007U 78080A   15223.34532704  .99999999  58108-5  10171-2 0  9994",                                                                
       "2 11007 062.2871 061.7119 0627378 263.5453 276.0639 15.20396923291974")
obj = ephem.readtle(*tle)
obj.compute()
obj.sublong
```

This satellite has recently decayed (last few weeks), which presumably is why it is causing this code to hang.  Is there a way to detect a decayed satellite before this hang?

items.title: Satellite elong is not computed
items.body:
When a satellite position is computed, the elong (angular separation from the Sun) is not computed and is left with a value of 0.

(The elong is directly related to phase angle, hence brightness.)

items.title: RA and Decs again, pyEphem vs Skyfield
items.body:
Hi Brandon

I'm still trying to use pyEphem and/or now skyfield to generate RA/Decs from TLEs for
a given date and place, so that I can match up trails on images with known orbits. The images have built in world coordinate systems (WCS) so I know the J2000.0 RA/Dec at a given point on the images so I want as close to possible equivalent RA/Dec from pyEphem, which from previous questions I believe is the .ra and .dec attributes/objects.

So for pyEphem I have

```
sat=ephem.readtle("SATNAME ", \
                  "1 38356U 12030A   14148.90924578  .00000000  00000-0  10000-3 0  5678",\
                  "2 38356   0.0481  47.9760 0002933 358.9451 332.7970  1.00270012  3866")
gatech = ephem.Observer()
gatech.lon, gatech.lat = '-5.47322222', '19.82561111'
gatech.elevation = 4194
gatech.date = '2014/01/02 07:05:52'
sat.compute(gatech)
print 'a_ra=',sat.a_ra,'a_dec=',sat.a_dec,'g_ra=',sat.g_ra,'g_dec=',sat.g_dec,'ra=',sat.ra,'dec=',sat.dec
```

which gives

```
a_ra= 1:15:36.95 a_dec= -2:32:29.9 g_ra= 1:14:10.55 g_dec= 0:06:09.8 ra= 1:16:19.75 dec= -2:28:04.6
```

doing what I assume to be the equivalent in skyfield

```
text = """
SATNAME
1 38356U 12030A   14148.90924578  .00000000  00000-0  10000-3 0  5678
2 38356   0.0481  47.9760 0002933 358.9451 332.7970  1.00270012  3866
"""
bluffton = earth.topos('19.82561111 N', '-5.47322222 E', elevation_m=4194.0)
tup = (2014, 1, 2, 7, 05, 52)
sat = earth.satellite(text)
astrometric = bluffton(utc=tup).observe(sat)

ra, dec, distance = astrometric.radec()
print(ra.hstr())
print(dec.dstr())
```

I get 01h 15m 44.42s -02deg 43' 00.9" which is close but not identical to pyEphem's
values of ra= 1:16:19.75 dec= -2:28:04.6.

Am I using skyfield wrongly and/or are the differences expected and/or with the accuracy of the calculations.

Thanks as always
Ad

items.title: Observer needs copy method (Feature request)
items.body:
Observers cannot by copied with either copy.copy() or copy.deepcopy().  (The result is an observer with all zeros).  Adding a copy method similar to that of Body.copy() would be helpful.

```
import ephem
import copy
gatech = ephem.Observer()
gatech.lon, gatech.lat = '-84.39733', '33.775867'
gatech.date = '2003/3/23 03:11:11'

gatech_copy = copy.copy(gatech)
gatech_deepcopy = copy.deepcopy(gatech)
print(gatech)
print(gatech_copy)
print(gatech_deepcopy)
```

gives

```
<ephem.Observer date='2003/3/23 03:11:11' epoch='2000/1/1 12:00:00' lon=-84:23:50.4 lat=33:46:33.1 elevation=0.0m horizon=0:00:00.0 temp=15.0C pressure=1010.0mBar>
<ephem.Observer date='1899/12/31 12:00:00' epoch='1899/12/31 12:00:00' lon=0:00:00.0 lat=0:00:00.0 elevation=0.0m horizon=0:00:00.0 temp=0.0C pressure=0.0mBar>
<ephem.Observer date='1899/12/31 12:00:00' epoch='1899/12/31 12:00:00' lon=0:00:00.0 lat=0:00:00.0 elevation=0.0m horizon=0:00:00.0 temp=0.0C pressure=0.0mBar>
```

My workaround:

```
class MyObserver(ephem.Observer):
    def copy(self):
        result = ephem.Observer()
        result.date = self.date
        result.epoch = self.epoch
        result.long = self.long
        result.lat = self.lat
        result.elev = self.elev
        result.temp = self.temp
        result.pressure = self.pressure
        result.horizon = self.horizon
        return result
```

items.title: moon.hlon do not give a heliocentric longitude, rather a geocentric one
items.body:
When creating a `Moon` object (`moon = ephem.Moon()`), and computing its `hlon` field at several times of a year, one can see that the result longitude is periodic, with 13 periods in one year.

So I guess that `moon.hlon` is actually a _geocentric_ longitude of the moon, rather than a _heliocentric_ one.

items.title: sun.hlon gives earth longitude w.r.t autumnal equinox and not vernal one
items.body:
when doing something like:

`sun = ephem.Sun()`

`sun.compute(date0)`

`lon_earth = sun.hlon`

to get the longitude of earth in the ecliptic plane, the `lon_earth` result is 0 for a `date0` corresponding to the autumnal equinox. 

That means the longitude is given in a coordinate system where the reference axis is 180° further away from the standard reference axis in an ecliptic system, i.e. the vernal equinox.

So bottom line is: That `sun.hlon` value should be referenced to vernal instead of autumnal equinox

items.title: Satellite position uncertainty
items.body:
I have been using PyEphem for the prediction of the position of LEO satellites and, right now, I am plotting that groundtrack over a map. I first define a timestep (T) and then run the simulator to get the position of the satellite at a sucession of times equally spaced by T [t, t+T, t+2T, ... ].

The attached image is the plot of the groundtrack obtained with the described method, for a 10 seconds timestep:

![screenshot from 2014-11-29 23 38 55](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5666358/5237114/749a3254-7820-11e4-92f1-c3d13ccc53bd.png)

It looks like for some of the longitudes, there is an increase in the uncertainty when it comes to estimate the position of the spacecraft; an issue that appears to lead to the obtained zig-zag lines. Am I correct? Has anybody observed this behavior previously?

As an intermediate solution, I was thinking on using a linear regression over the generated points.

items.title: previous_rising() modifies the observer date, contradicting the documentation
items.body:
Regarding the eight Observer methods for finding rise/transit/set times, the documentation says they "Always leaves the Observer unmodified.".

However, in 3.7.5.1, I found that previous_rising() leaves an observer with a new date after an AlwaysUpError. This program shows the discrepancy:

```
#!/usr/bin/python

import ephem

np = ephem.Observer()
np.lon = 0 * ephem.degree
np.lat = 90 * ephem.degree
np.elevation = 0
np.date = ephem.Date("2015/05/30 00:00:00")

np_sun = ephem.Sun()
print(np.date)
try:
    np.previous_rising(np_sun)
except ephem.AlwaysUpError:
    print(np.date)
```

Giving the output:

```
2015/5/30 00:00:00
2015/5/29 23:57:25
```

Nothing in the changelog led me to think that any version subsequent to 3.7.5.1 fixed this.

items.title: Non-consecutive rise,transit,set times
items.body:
This is a re-opening of issue #38  (Observer.next_pass returns set time that is before rise time)

That was closed because the satellite was a GEO bird that therefore had poorly-defined rise,transit set times.

Here is a simple case with a LEO satellite (the ISS) which also shows the problem.  It may be partially due to the fact that, at the compute() time, the satellite is above the horizon.

```
# Minimal example of non-consecutive rise,transit,set
import ephem
print("ephem.__version__ = ",ephem.__version__)

iss = ephem.readtle("ISS (ZARYA)",
  "1 25544U 98067A   03097.78853147  .00021906  00000-0  28403-3 0  8652",
  "2 25544  51.6361  13.7980 0004256  35.6671  59.2566 15.58778559250029")

gatech = ephem.Observer()
gatech.lon, gatech.lat = '-84.39733', '33.775867'
gatech.date = '2003/3/23 03:17:11'
iss.compute(gatech)
np = gatech.next_pass(iss)
next_pass_times = np[::2]
print("Next pass rise,transit,set",list((d.datetime().strftime("%H:%M:%S ") for d in next_pass_times)))
```

Output is 

```
ephem.__version__ =  3.7.5.3
Next pass rise,transit,set ['04:49:53 ', '03:18:54 ', '03:20:18 ']
```

If you use a start time 
`gatech.date = '2003/3/23 03:00:11'` 
(at which time ISS is below the horizon), you get a valid, monotonically increasing rise,transit,set
`['03:10:48 ', '03:15:29 ', '03:20:11 ']`
Note that the transit time is several minutes away from that for the pathological case.

items.title: ephem.Date switches between Julian and Gregorian
items.body:
This is not what I expected to happen at all:

``` python
j = -115860

ephem.Date(j)
'1582/10/4 12:00:00'

ephem.Date(j + 1)
'1582/10/15 12:00:00'
```

I understand that using the proleptic Gregorian isn't as common as using the Julian calendar, but I suggest that a note about this behavior be added to the docs.

items.title: Precession, Proper Motion, and Epochs for Ancient or Future Observers
items.body:
I have a question regarding epochs. I want to show the night sky as a super-ancient observer would see it or someone in the far flung future. Should I set the year _and_ epoch to be the same? I have an ipython notebook here ([proper-motion.ipynb](https://github.com/digitalvapor/asterisms/blob/master/notebooks/proper-motion.ipynb) / [nbviewer](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/github/digitalvapor/asterisms/blob/master/notebooks/proper-motion.ipynb)) with the equivalent code. The following discussion on equatorial telescopes in [the precession and epochs tutorial](http://rhodesmill.org/pyephem/tutorial.html#fixed-objects-precession-and-epochs) and the below example on Halley's Comet seem sure thing to me to use both year and epoch as the same. However, I found some conflicting results from a few other people. > When planning to observe with an equatorial telescope, you may want to use the current date as your epoch, because the rotation of the sky above your telescope is determined by where the pole points today, not where it pointed in 2000 or some other convenient epoch. Computing positions in the epoch of their date is accomplished by simply providing the same argument for both date and epoch: ``` >>> j = ephem.Jupiter() >>> j.compute(epoch=ephem.now()) # so both date and epoch are now >>> print("%s %s" % (j.a_ra, j.a_dec)) # doctest: +SKIP 8:44:29.49 19:00:10.23 >>> j.compute('2003/3/25', epoch='2003/3/25') >>> print("%s %s" % (j.a_ra, j.a_dec)) 8:43:32.82 19:03:32.5 ``` ![uma_proper_motion](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2218331/5384024/195231fa-806b-11e4-8181-94866b3d3582.png) Ian Ridpath gives a talk, _Pictures in the sky: the origin and history of the constellations_, that displays an animation of the same transition. See the [video at t=2563](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nZm-QaKqS-Y#t=2563). Jones got his images from Rick Pogge's [video](http://www.astronomy.ohio-state.edu/~pogge/Ast162/Movies/proper.html) and lecture which was output from his Fortran code. I read the PyEphem tutorial section on [fixed objects, precession, and epochs](http://rhodesmill.org/pyephem/tutorial.html#fixed-objects-precession-and-epochs). This computes the position of [Halley's Comet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Halley's_Comet) in 1066. > **halley.compute(epoch='1066')**
> This is probably useless: it computes the current position of halley, but returns coordinates relative to the direction the earth’s axis was pointing in the year 1066. Unless you use a Conquest-era star atlas, this is not useful. > > **halley.compute('1066', epoch='1066')**
> This is slightly more promising: it computes the position of halley in 1066 and returns coordinates for the orientation of the earth in that year. This might help you visualize how the object was positioned above contemporary observers, who considered it an ill omen in the imminent conflict between King Harold of England and William the Bastard. But to plot this position against a background of stars, you would first have to recompute each star’s position in 1066 coordinates. > > **halley.compute('1066')**
> This is what you will probably use most often; you get the position of halley in the year 1066 but expressed in the 2000 coordinates that your star atlas probably uses. I am a little confused by Ridpath's, Pogge's and Jones' ([paper here](http://www.unc.edu/~marzuola/Math547_S14/Projects/M_Jones.pdf)) results. Although I am happy that we can get the stellar dustpan and butterfly net they talk about, why are they using coordinates relative to our current position? Wouldnt using the ancient epoch and far flung future epoch _and_ year give results for how ancient or future man would see these stars instead? Based on the second Halley's Comet example Brandon Rhodes gives, I am going to go with the following as what I think the depictions of the precession of the Big Dipper are. ![uma_transition](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2218331/5384038/3e80a42a-806b-11e4-8992-9aa126b0befd.png) ``` %pylab inline import ephem UMa = { 'dubhe': 'αUMa', #HIP 54061 'merak': 'βUMa', #HIP 53910 'phecda':'γUMa', #HIP 58001 'megrez':'δUMa', #HIP 59774 'alioth':'εUMa', #HIP 62956 'mizar': 'ζUMa', #HIP 65378 'alcor': '80UMa',#HIP 65477 'alcaid':'ηUMa', #HIP 67301 } def const(const,year=None,epoch='2000',title=None): s = [] for star in const.keys(): s.append(ephem.star(star.capitalize())) for i in range(len(s)): if(year!=None): s[i].compute(year,epoch=epoch) else: s[i].compute(epoch=epoch) tau = 2.0 * pi degree = tau / 360.0 hour = tau / 24.0 ra_list = [star.a_ra / hour for star in s] dec_list = [star.a_dec / degree for star in s] mag_array = np.array([star.mag for star in s]) size_array = (5 - mag_array) ** 1.5 * 4 scatter(ra_list,dec_list,size_array) if(title!=None): pyplot.title(title) gca().xaxis.grid(True) gca().yaxis.grid(True) gca().invert_xaxis() return s ``` The function can be called with the following to test: **Setting Epoch and Year to Same Thing:** - `ancient_uma = const(UMa,year='-100000',epoch='-100000',title='Desk Lamp')` - `present_uma = const(UMa,year='2014',epoch='2014',title='Current Big Dipper (Epoch 2014)')` - `future_uma = const(UMa,year='100000',epoch='100000',title='Kite')` **Only Changing Year and Leaving Epoch as 2000:** - `ancient_uma = const(UMa,year='-100000',title='Butterfly Net')` - `present_uma = const(UMa,year='2014',title='Big Dipper (Epoch 2000)')` - `future_uma = const(UMa,year='100000',title='Dustpan')`

items.title: EarthSatellite calculations go haywire ~1 year away from now()
items.body:
Using pyephem 3.7.5.3.  Example code:

``` python
import ephem

sat = ephem.readtle(
    "INTELSAT 1 F-1",
    "1 01317U 65028A   14295.55725898  .00000126  00000-0  00000+0 0  5379",
    "2 01317 002.4226 295.9730 0007646 198.7956 298.3366 01.00279102 84510")

obs = ephem.Observer()
obs.lon = '-111:32.1'
obs.lat = '35:05.8'
obs.elevation = 2198

now = ephem.now()
Ndays = 370 * 2
for day in range(Ndays + 1):
    day = day - Ndays/2
    obs.date = now + day
    sat.compute(obs)
    print "day %i: %s" % (day, obs.date)
    print "alt=%s az=%s ra=%s dec=%s sublat=%s sublong=%s" % \
        (sat.alt, sat.az, sat.ra, sat.dec, sat.sublat.norm, sat.sublong.norm)
```

for -367 < day < 363 there is normal, believable output:

> day 0: 2014/10/24 22:52:54

items.title: Body position (sublat, sublong) return nan when readtle() supplied >1 year old
items.body: I've noticed that when the body position is computed using a >1 year old TLE that the sublat and sublong values are often (always?) returned as "nan." This threshold seems so close to 1 year that I am wondering if it is even set by pyephem or a dependency to a 1 year validity range. I know TLEs contain errors and have finite precision, but shouldn't one in theory be able to compute position for more than one year from a given TLE?

items.title: Satellite next_pass() does not use observer.horizon
items.body:
The next_pass function ignores the observer.horizon value and assumes a zero-elevation horizon.

A documentation fix may be adequate if this is too deeply embedded in the Xephem library for you to easily fix.

Also in the documentation, should the [2] and [3] elements of the output be 'culmination' (the highest point in the path) rather than 'transit'.  I think traditionally 'transit' refers to crossing the meridian, which for  stars is also culmination.  I don't know how the word is used by satellite watchers.  Any change to this should be in the documentation only, since presumably everyone who cares is already using [2] and[3] for what they are.

(If you have a German Equatorial Mount, transiting the meridian is still an interesting point, even if you also care about culmination.)

items.title: sat.dec and sat.ra switch from geocentric to topocentric after observer update.
items.body:
Thanks for writing this library, I've made extensive use of it.
However, I was confused why my satellite changed positions after setting the range by updating a ground station. Here's an example:

``` python
>import ephem
>sat = ephem.readtle(some_tle)
>gs = ephem.Observer()
>epoch = some_time
>sat.update(epoch)

>sat.g_ra #geocentric
1:00:00
>sat.ra  #also geocentric

>sat.g_ra #still geocentric
1:00:00

57:01:23.4
```

The quick references says you can use (ra _or_ g_ra)/(dec _or_ g_dec) for geocentric location-maybe switch that to _only_ g_+\* varibles? Or setting .ra and .dec as `None` until you update with an observer?

items.title: Request for new version using XEphem 3.7.6

Hi Brandon,

Do you have an estimate for when you might do the next release?  I have a couple of reasons...

1) To pick up the fixes you've made since the last release of 3.7.5.3, namely issue #44 (I have put in the workaround you suggested and all is good), but mainly,

Cheers,

Bernard.

items.title: PyEphem disagreeing with Orbitron
items.body:
Dear all,
I am currently using PyEphem for a Django application through the following script:

```
def calculate_pass_slot(observer, body, start, end):
    pass_slots = []
    observer.date = start
    last_end = start

    while last_end < end:

        tr, azr, tt, altt, ts, azs = observer.next_pass(body)

        dt_tr = misc.localize_datetime_utc(tr.datetime())
        dt_ts = misc.localize_datetime_utc(ts.datetime())

        if dt_tr > end:
            break
        if dt_ts > end:
            pass_slots.append((dt_tr, end))
        else:
            pass_slots.append((dt_tr, dt_ts))

        observer.date = ts + ephem.minute
        last_end = misc.localize_datetime_utc(observer.date.datetime())

    return pass_slots
```

The results for a one day simulation on 24th June 2014 (today) is the following:

```
# ### Observer (Ground Station):
* (lat, long) = (34:03:07.9, 118:14:31.9)
* elevation = 17.0
* horizon = 10:18:02.6

```

That differ from the ones by Orbitron:

Anybody has had this problem before? What am I doing wrong?

items.title: Feature request: document “circumpolar” and “neverup” attributes
items.body:
Hi Brandon, 

Great package you've put together - makes my life so very easy!

When computing a satellite's next pass, is it possible to discriminate when the satellite is always up or never up, rather than just getting a value error?

In the script below, I deliberately set a latitude to trigger a value error.  What would be nice is to know if the satellite is always up or never up (or some other "real" error).

``` python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import ephem

ephemNow = ephem.now()

observer = ephem.Observer()
observer.lat = "80"
observer.lon = "0"
observer.date = ephemNow

satellite = ephem.readtle(
    "ISS (ZARYA)",
    "1 25544U 98067A   14173.77860341  .00009574  00000-0  17035-3 0  5510",
    "2 25544  51.6472  71.8399 0004130 124.0235 340.8701 15.50853765892196" )

try:
    print( observer.next_pass( satellite )[ 0 ] )
except ephem.AlwaysUpError:
    print( "AlwaysUpError" )
except ephem.NeverUpError:
    print( "NeverUpError" )
except ephem.CircumpolarError:
    print( "CircumpolarError" )
except ValueError:
    print( "ValueError" )
```

Thanks in advance,

Bernard.

items.title: Python3 Ephem seg faults on copy.copy( body )
items.body:
Hi,

I'm using PyEphem 3.7.5.3 which I download as source and then upload to my PPA (http://launchpad.net/~thebernmeister/+archive/ppa) to be used in my indicator-lunar, running as Python3, Ubuntu 14.04 64 bit.

Using the prior version, 3.7.5.1, there was no problem.  However this new version causes a segmentation fault when attempting to copy a body object.  I can get around this seg fault by using copy.deepcopy(), but I suspect this isn't really working as later on I get a core dump when trying to ephem.Ecliptic( bodyCopy ).

``` python
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import copy, ephem

print( "PyEphem:", ephem.__version__ )

ephemNow = ephem.now()

city = ephem.city( "Sydney" )
city.date = ephemNow

sun = ephem.Sun( city )

# Issue 1: copy.copy( sun ) causes
#     Segmentation fault (core dumped)
# but copy.deepcopy( sun ) is fine.
sunCopy = copy.deepcopy( sun )

# Subset of code from indicator-lunar
( year, month, day ) = ephemNow.triple()
epochAdjusted = float( year ) + float( month ) / 12.0 + float( day ) / 365.242
ephemNowDate = str( ephemNow ).split( " " )
print( "epochAdjusted:", epochAdjusted )
print( "ephemNowDate:", ephemNowDate )
sunCopy.compute( ephemNowDate[ 0 ], epoch = str( epochAdjusted ) )

# Issue 2: Assuming copy.deepcopy( sun ) is used above rather than
# copy.copy( sun ), the computing the ecliptic on sunCopy aborts with
#     obj_cir() called with type 0 
#     Aborted (core dumped)
sunCopyEcliptic = ephem.Ecliptic( sunCopy )
```

If I comment out the copy code in my indicator (the only place a copy occurs), all is well using 3.7.5.3...so I'm guessing something has changed between versions of PyEphem (or the underlying XEphem library)?

Thanks in advance,

Bernard.

items.title: Compatibility break - ephem.Galactic().long returnes AttributeError
items.body:
Version 3.7.4.1 (2011 January 5) change lo says:
"Renamed the Observer.long attribute to lon after realizing that the official syllabification of “longitude” is “lon·gi·tude.” Also changed Body objects so that hlong is hlon instead. The old names will always be supported for compatibility with older programs."

However! The ephem.Galactic().long was also changed to ephem.Galactic().lon, but the 'long' version was NOT retained for future compatibility (as it was with the Observer class). Now my older programs return AttributeError

I have tested on 3.7.5.1 (Galactic.long does not work, Galactic.lon works)
and on version 3.7.3.4 (Galactic.long works, Galactic.lon does not work)

I am guessing, that other classes that used 'long', could have the same problem.

items.title: ephem.Date(datetime.now()) looses float-second precision
items.body:
``` python
import ephem
from datetime import datetime
x = datetime.now()
# datetime(2014, 4, 8, 21, 14, 17, 667000)
ephem.Date(x).tuple()
# (2014, 4, 8, 21, 14, 17.000000425614417)
```

So somehow ephem.Date manages to convert datetime objects but looses half of it. What is the logic here? Convert datetime to string and parse it?

This is a very dangerous thing if you don't expect it.

I use this in my code now:

``` python
d = ephem.Date((x.year, x.month, x.day, x.hour, x.minute, x.second + x.microsecond/10**6))
```

items.title: Observer.next_pass returns set time that is before rise time
items.body:
This is a specific case likely associated with #2 and wondering if anyone has a workaround.

I have encountered some cases where the chronology of rise/set time for next_pass does not make sense.  Example case from Celestrak where you can see the set time is earlier than rise time:

```
import ephem, datetime
boston = ephem.city('Boston')
boston.date = datetime.datetime(2014, 3, 31, 23, 30, 17, 899671)
body = ephem.readtle('SIRIUS-1',
                     '1 26390U 00035A   14089.46488652 -.00000046  00000-0  00000+0 0  3087',
                     '2 26390  60.0759 240.4423 2664442 270.1712 107.9086  1.00273291 50366')
rise_time, _, _, _, set_time, _ = boston.next_pass(body)
print "Observer date: %s" % boston.date
print "Rise date: %s" % rise_time
print "Set date: %s" % set_time
```

Output:

```
﻿Observer date: 2014/3/31 23:30:17
Rise date: 2014/4/1 05:39:28
Set date: 2014/4/1 00:49:37
```

I am not sure if this is an upstream XEphem issue or not.  I found this note in the XEphem docs:

> Due to their generally rapid motions Earth satellites often have many rising and setting events per day. For this reason, the rise and set time for satellites are not restrained to be during the current local day. Rather, for satellites, XEphem displays the very next rising and setting events that occur strictly later than the current time on the Main window, provided they occur within 24 hours. This means that if the rise or set time displayed is earlier than the current local time on the Main window, it actually refers to the next day. 

I wonder if something similar is going on here and this is actually supposed to wrap to the next day?

items.title: Ephem does not agree with the ESRL/NASA/NOAA sun position calculator
items.body:
The attached show solar altitude calculations on one day for a location in brooklyn, ny. For completeness the calculations show the sun position with and without refraction (by setting pressure = 0, per ephem documentation).  And as an approximation the angular radius of the sun is added to the result in both cases.  Thus the graphs have four curves.

Compare the numbers from the graph to the numbers produced at the following link, and you will see that they do not agree.   http://www.esrl.noaa.gov/gmd/grad/solcalc/

![Uploading sunrise.zoom.png . . .]()

And here is the code that generates the image

```
#!/bin/python

from datetime import date, datetime

import math
import ephem

from pylab import *

matplotlib.rc('xtick', labelsize=10) 
matplotlib.rc('ytick', labelsize=10) 

# some useful functions

def degrees( a ) : return ((a/math.pi)*180.)
def radians( a ) : return ((a/180.)*math.pi)
def daytime( a ) : t=a.tuple() ; return "%2d:%02d:%02d"%(t[3],t[4],t[5])

# calculation for graphs
def calcf( d0, d1, sun, obs, tz ):

    air = obs.pressure

    dates = []

    rawalts = []
    toprawalts = []

    airalts = []
    topairalts = []

    obs.horizon = '0'
    while d0 < d1:

        d0 += ephem.second

        dloc = ephem.Date(d0 + tz *ephem.hour)
        dates.append( dloc.datetime() )

        obs.date = d0

        obs.pressure = 0
        sun.compute(obs)
        rawalts.append( degrees(sun.alt) )
        toprawalts.append( degrees(sun.alt)+sunradius )

        obs.pressure = air
        sun.compute(obs)
        airalts.append( degrees(sun.alt) )
        topairalts.append( degrees(sun.alt)+sunradius )

    return dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts

# ==========================================================

def graphf( dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts, titletext, filename):

    figure(1, figsize=(10,8), dpi=300 )

    plot( dates, rawalts, 'r', label='raw' )
    l = plot( dates, toprawalts, 'r', label='raw + sun angular radius' )
    setp( l, linestyle='--' )

    plot( dates, airalts, 'b', label='with refraction' )
    l = plot( dates, topairalts, 'b', label='with refr + sun angular radius' )
    setp( l, linestyle='--', color='b' )

    ylabel( "sun altitude in degrees" )

    grid(True)
    legend(loc='best')

    title( titletext )

    savefig( filename )

    clf()

# ==========================================================

# data for alte rebbe sunset
mtcarmel=2224.0
mtcarmelprominence=1804
earthradius=6371000.0

alterebbeangle = math.acos( earthradius / ( earthradius + mtcarmelprominence ) )
alterebbeangle = degrees(alterebbeangle)

# setup observer at 770
o770 = ephem.Observer()
o770.lat, o770.lon = '40.669021', '-73.942870'
o770.date = ephem.Date( datetime.datetime.utcnow() )
tz = -5

air = o770.pressure

# setup for sun and moon calculations
sun, moon = ephem.Sun(), ephem.Moon()

# compute for observer at 770
sun.compute(o770)
moon.compute(o770)

sunradius = (32.7/60.0)/2.0

# adjust reference to noon today
o770.date = o770.next_transit(sun)

sunrise = o770.previous_rising(sun)
localsunrise = ephem.Date( sunrise + tz * ephem.hour )

noon = o770.next_transit(sun)
print "noon" , noon
localnoon = ephem.Date( noon + tz * ephem.hour )
print "localnoon", localnoon

sunset = o770.next_setting(sun)
localsunset = ephem.Date( sunset + tz * ephem.hour )

# =======================================

d0 = sunrise - 40 * ephem.minute
d1 = sunrise + 10 * ephem.minute

dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts = calcf( d0, d1, sun, o770, tz )

titletext = "Sunrise at (%s,%s)\n%s"%(o770.lat,o770.lon,localsunrise.datetime())

graphf( dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts, titletext, "sunrise.png" )

# =======================================

d0 = sunrise - 6 * ephem.minute
d1 = sunrise + 4 * ephem.minute

dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts = calcf( d0, d1, sun, o770, tz )

titletext = "Sunrise at (%s,%s)\n%s"%(o770.lat,o770.lon,localsunrise.datetime())

graphf( dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts, titletext, "sunrise.zoom.png" )

# =======================================

d0 = sunset - 10 * ephem.minute
d1 = sunset + 40 * ephem.minute

dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts = calcf( d0, d1, sun, o770, tz )

titletext = "Sunset at (%s,%s)\n%s"%(o770.lat,o770.lon,localsunset.datetime())

graphf( dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts, titletext, "sunset.png" )

# =======================================

d0 = sunset - 4 * ephem.minute
d1 = sunset + 6 * ephem.minute

dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts = calcf( d0, d1, sun, o770, tz )

titletext = "Sunset at (%s,%s)\n%s"%(o770.lat,o770.lon,localsunset.datetime())

graphf( dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts, titletext, "sunset.zoom.png" )

# =======================================

d0 = noon - 30 * ephem.minute
d1 = noon + 30 * ephem.minute

dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts = calcf( d0, d1, sun, o770, tz )

titletext = "Solar noon at (%s,%s)\n%s"%(o770.lat,o770.lon,localnoon.datetime())

graphf( dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts, titletext, "solarnoon.png" )

# =======================================

d0 = sunrise - 30 * ephem.minute
d1 = sunset + 30 * ephem.minute

dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts = calcf( d0, d1, sun, o770, tz )

titletext = "Solar noon at (%s,%s)\n%s"%(o770.lat,o770.lon,localnoon.datetime())

graphf( dates, rawalts, toprawalts, airalts, topairalts, titletext, "solarday.png" )



```

items.title: Possible documentation error - Does pyephem use UT1 not UTC?
items.body:
The PyEpem documentation says that all times are UTC, but I suspect that they are really UT1.  For UTC, `ephem.delta_t` should have discontinuities at the leap seconds but I get a smooth function when I plot it:

``` python
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import ephem

jd = ephem.Date('2013/10/31') - np.arange(10 * 365)  # roughly past 10 years.
delta = []
for this_jd in jd:
    delta.append(ephem.delta_t(str(ephem.Date(this_jd))))

plt.plot(jd, delta)
plt.xlabel('Dublin Julian Date (days)')
plt.ylabel('delta_t (s)')
plt.show()
# See attached plot.
```

![delta_t](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/399263/1449183/13c53318-4264-11e3-8475-caab06f79846.png)

items.title: ephem ignores the microseconds in `datetime.datetime` objects.
items.body:
`ephem` seems to be ignoring the microseconds in the builtin datetime objects.  I've pasted three examples below.  The first two should not give identical output.  In the third, I convert to a string first and this seems to work fine.

```
>>> import ephem
>>> import datetime
>>> ephem.date(datetime.datetime(2000, 12, 25, 12, 41, 16, 10))
36884.028657407405
>>> ephem.date(datetime.datetime(2000, 12, 25, 12, 41, 16, 10000))
36884.028657407405
>>> ephem.date(str(datetime.datetime(2000, 12, 25, 12, 41, 16, 10000)))
36884.02865752315
>>> ephem.__version__
'3.7.5.1'
```

items.title: Pyephem hangs after body.compute when accessing computed values for some satellite cases
items.body:
First off - wonderful package! Thanks so much for all the great work on this.

[I'm using pyephem version 3.7.5.1]

I've run into an issue where the body.compute can hang when calculating positions for satellites. I ran into a similar issue on stack overflow that seems to also be what I am experiencing but no one appears to have answered that issue.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/13298089/error-trapping-ephem-body-compute-for-earth-satellite-objects

To summarize the problem: if I run the code below it's ok through the body.compute() call but then if you try to access any of the computed values python's CPU usage goes to 100% and the program hangs. There does not even appear to be a way to trap an error to avoid this. I have a program that is computing many satellite positions and the only way I've found to get around this issue is to call the computation as a thread in the multiprocessing module and then kill it if it times out. Not a very nice solution. If anyone has any suggestions for how to avoid this is would be especially appreciated.

Code demonstrating bug:

```
import ephem

obj = ephem.readtle("FENGYUN 1C DEB", "1 31034U 99025BEC 12293.69998868  .02147743  29582-2  52063-2 0  1666","2 31034 099.0270 256.6567 0044344 106.5074 254.5558 15.95183245303888")

obs.lon = '-111.011647'
obs.elevation = 400
obs.name = 'myObs'
obs.date = '2012/11/9 01:52:48'

obj.compute(obs) # This returns

# Ok to here but if you call any computed property it just hangs such as
print obj.ra # This causes 100% CPU usage and hangs
```

items.title: Freezes (in libastro) on tricky satellites
items.body:
When a satellite is tricky, ephem can freeze inside the libastro library.

As an example, here is a satellite that decays so that it is no longer visible between the date of the epoch and the date of the observation.
    # This freezes in the library

```
import ephem
import math
import datetime
import sys

print(ephem.__version__)


tle=["OBJECT L",
"1 39276U 13055L   13275.56815576  .28471697  00000-0  53764+0 0    92",
"2 39276 080.9963 312.3419 0479021 141.2713 225.6381 14.71846910   412"]


def FentonObserver() :
    fenton=ephem.Observer()
    fenton.long='-106.673887'
    fenton.lat='35.881226'
    fenton.elevation=2656
    fenton.horizon=math.radians(10)
    fenton.temp=0.0
    fenton.compute_pressure()
    return fenton

sat = ephem.readtle(*tle)

obs = FentonObserver()
utc = datetime.timezone.utc
obs.date = datetime.datetime(2013,10,6,0,0,0,0,utc)
print(obs)
sys.stdout.flush()
sat.compute(obs)
print(sat)
sys.stdout.flush()
print(sat.neverup)      # Freezes when trying to access neverup
```

I tried to work-around it with the @timelimit decorator http://code.activestate.com/recipes/483752/, but when inside the library it doesn't respond to interrupts, so I have no way of recovering.

items.title: Calculation of Parallactic Angle
items.body:
I'd like to request a method for calculating the parallactic angle of an object given an observer.  I suspect this is a commonly used quantity and would be useful to other users.

Below is the code for a quick and dirty function I wrote to do the calculation along with an example call.  It's a bit inconsistent as I'm using astropy units to keep track of degrees vs. radians rather than an ephem angle.

As I note in the doc string below, I merely used an equation I pulled from a google search.  It appears to work in a **single test case**, but I did not try any edge cases (angles near the pole, etc.), so this may not be the best formula to use.

```
from math import sin, cos, tan, atan
import astropy.units as u
import ephem

##-------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Parallactic Angle
##-------------------------------------------------------------------------
def ParallacticAngle(HA, dec, lat):
    '''
    Function to calcualte the parallactic angle.

    Equations from:
    "A treatise on spherical astronomy" By Sir Robert Stawell Ball
    (p. 91, as viewed on Google Books)

    sin(eta)*sin(z) = cos(lat)*sin(HA)
    cos(eta)*sin(z) = sin(lat)*cos(dec) - cos(lat)*sin(dec)*cos(HA)

    Where eta is the parallactic angle, z is the zenith angle, lat is the
    observer's latitude, dec is the declination, and HA is the hour angle.

    thus:

    tan(eta) = cos(lat)*sin(HA) / (sin(lat)*cos(dec)-cos(lat)*sin(dec)*cos(HA))
    '''
    assert type(HA) == u.quantity.Quantity
    assert type(dec) == u.quantity.Quantity
    assert type(lat) == u.quantity.Quantity
    HArad = HA.to(u.radian).value
    latrad = lat.to(u.radian).value
    decrad = dec.to(u.radian).value
    taneta = cos(latrad)*sin(HArad) / (sin(latrad)*cos(decrad) - cos(latrad)*sin(decrad)*cos(HArad))
    return atan(taneta)*u.radian

##-------------------------------------------------------------------------
## Main Program
##-------------------------------------------------------------------------
def main():
    ## set up target as a fixed object in ephem
    ## set up subaru as an observer object
    target.compute(subaru)
    HA = subaru.sidereal_time() - target.ra
    PA = ParallacticAngle(HA*u.radian, float(target.dec)*u.radian, float(subaru.lat)*u.radian)

```
